metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: identify fields as static or changing, and as uniform or non-uniform

static_field_definition.name: Static Field Definition
static_field_definition.correct: A static field does not change over time. It remains constant in magnitude and direction at every point.

a field that doesn't move through space.fix: Static refers to time, not position. A static field is unchanging, not unmoving.
a field that doesn't move through space.action: Ask: does the field strength at any point change over time? If no, it's static.

a field with zero strength.error: Static doesn't mean zero or absent.
a field with zero strength.fix: Static means constant, not zero. A strong field can be static if it doesn't change.
a field with zero strength.action: Earth's gravitational field is static near the surface. It's not zero.

a field created by stationary charges on.error: Too narrow. Any unchanging field is static.
a field created by stationary charges on.fix: Static describes the field, not what creates it. Constant current creates static magnetic field.
a field created by stationary charges on.action: A solenoid with constant current produces a static magnetic field.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding what 'static' means for fields.
persistent.action: Static = unchanging over time. Check if field strength at any point varies. If constant, it's static.

changing_field_definition.name: Changing Field Definition
changing_field_definition.correct: A changing field varies in magnitude or direction over time at one or more points in space.

a field that moves through space.error: Changing refers to time variation, not spatial movement.
a field that moves through space.fix: A changing field has time-dependent strength or direction at fixed points.
a field that moves through space.action: Watch one point in space. Does the field there change? If yes, the field is changing.

a field with different values at differe.fix: Changing = varies with time. Non-uniform = varies with position. Different concepts.
a field with different values at differe.action: Changing: varies at same point over time. Non-uniform: varies across different points.

a field that only exists temporarily.fix: A changing field can exist indefinitely while continuously varying.
a field that only exists temporarily.action: AC circuits produce changing magnetic fields that persist as long as current flows.

persistent.gap: You're confusing time variation with spatial variation or existence.
persistent.action: Changing = field at a fixed point varies over time. This is independent of spatial variation.

static_field_sources.name: Sources of Static Fields
static_field_sources.correct: Static fields are produced by stationary charges, stationary masses, stationary magnets, or constant (DC) currents.

only by permanent magnets.error: Too restrictive. Many sources create static fields.
only by permanent magnets.fix: Stationary charges create static electric fields. Constant currents create static magnetic fields.
only by permanent magnets.action: List static field sources: stationary mass, stationary charge, stationary magnet, constant current.

only by moving charges.error: Moving charges create changing fields, not static ones.
only by moving charges.fix: Moving charges produce changing fields. Stationary charges produce static fields.
only by moving charges.action: Compare: stationary electron (static E field) vs moving electron (changing fields).

only in a vacuum.error: Medium doesn't determine if a field is static.
only in a vacuum.fix: Static fields exist in any medium. It's about time variation, not where the field exists.
only in a vacuum.action: Earth's gravitational field is static in air, water, or vacuum.

persistent.gap: You don't know what creates static vs changing fields.
persistent.action: Rule: stationary or constant sources → static field. Moving or varying sources → changing field.

changing_field_sources.name: Sources of Changing Fields
changing_field_sources.correct: Changing fields are produced by moving charges, moving magnets, or time-varying (AC) currents.

only by AC circuits.error: Too restrictive. Any moving source creates changing fields.
only by AC circuits.fix: Moving magnets, moving charges, and varying currents all produce changing fields.
only by AC circuits.action: Waving a bar magnet creates a changing magnetic field, no AC needed.

only by electromagnetic waves.error: EM waves contain changing fields, but aren't the only source.
only by electromagnetic waves.fix: Any moving charge or varying current creates changing fields. EM waves are one result.
only by electromagnetic waves.action: Simply moving a charged object creates changing electric and magnetic fields.

only in conductors.error: Changing fields exist in space, not just in materials.
only in conductors.fix: A moving magnet creates a changing field in the space around it, not just in nearby conductors.
only in conductors.action: Move a magnet in empty space. The field there changes with time.

persistent.gap: You're limiting changing fields to specific contexts.
persistent.action: Any time-varying source creates changing fields. Motion or variation → field changes.

uniform_field_definition.name: Uniform Field Definition
uniform_field_definition.correct: A uniform field has the same magnitude and direction at all points in space. Field lines are parallel and evenly spaced.

a field with constant strength only.error: Magnitude alone isn't enough. Direction must also be constant.
a field with constant strength only.fix: Uniform means both magnitude AND direction are the same everywhere.
a field with constant strength only.action: Check both: Is strength the same? Is direction the same? Both must be yes.

a field that doesn't change with time.fix: Uniform = same at all points in space. Static = same at all times. Different concepts.
a field that doesn't change with time.action: Uniform: spatial uniformity. Static: temporal constancy. Independent properties.

any field with parallel lines.error: Lines must also be evenly spaced, not just parallel.
any field with parallel lines.fix: Parallel but unequally spaced lines show a field that varies in strength.
any field with parallel lines.action: Uniform field: parallel AND evenly spaced lines. Check both conditions.

persistent.gap: You're not applying all conditions for uniformity.
persistent.action: Uniform field = same magnitude + same direction at all points. Draw parallel, evenly spaced lines.

nonuniform_field_definition.name: Non-uniform Field Definition
nonuniform_field_definition.formula: Magnitude or direction varies with position
nonuniform_field_definition.correct: A non-uniform field varies in magnitude or direction across different locations. Field lines converge, diverge, or curve.

a field that changes with time.error: That's a changing field, not non-uniform.
a field that changes with time.fix: Non-uniform = varies across space. Changing = varies over time. Different concepts.
a field that changes with time.action: Non-uniform: different at point A vs point B. Changing: different at time 1 vs time 2.

a field with no pattern.error: Non-uniform fields have definite patterns, just not uniform ones.
a field with no pattern.fix: Radial fields are non-uniform but follow precise mathematical patterns (inverse square law).
a field with no pattern.action: Earth's gravity is non-uniform (weaker at altitude) but follows a clear pattern.

a field that only exists in some regions.error: Non-uniform doesn't mean partial or incomplete.
a field that only exists in some regions.fix: Non-uniform fields exist everywhere in their domain, just with varying strength.
a field that only exists in some regions.action: Earth's gravitational field exists everywhere but is non-uniform (varies with altitude).

persistent.gap: You're confusing spatial variation with other field properties.
persistent.action: Non-uniform = field differs at different locations. Radial fields from point sources are always non-uniform.

uniform_field_examples.name: Uniform Field Examples
uniform_field_examples.correct: Uniform fields include the electric field between parallel charged plates and the gravitational field near Earth's surface (approximation).

the field around a point charge.error: Point charges create radial, non-uniform fields.
the field around a point charge.fix: Point sources create fields that spread out and weaken with distance. Not uniform.
the field around a point charge.action: Draw field lines from a point charge. They radiate outward. Not parallel.

the magnetic field of a bar magnet.error: Bar magnets create dipole fields, which are non-uniform.
the magnetic field of a bar magnet.fix: Bar magnet field lines curve from N to S pole. They're not parallel or evenly spaced.
the magnetic field of a bar magnet.action: Sketch bar magnet field. Lines are curved and closer together near poles.

any field close to its source.fix: Close to a point source, the field is strongest but still non-uniform (still follows 1/r²).
any field close to its source.action: Near a point charge, the field is strong but still radial, not uniform.

persistent.gap: You're not recognising which configurations produce uniform fields.
persistent.action: Uniform fields: parallel plates, inside long solenoid, near Earth's surface (approximation).

nonuniform_field_examples.name: Non-uniform Field Examples
nonuniform_field_examples.correct: Non-uniform fields include those around point masses, point charges, bar magnets, and planetary gravitational fields at large scales.

the field between parallel plates.fix: Between parallel charged plates, E-field is constant in magnitude and direction.
the field between parallel plates.action: Draw field between parallel plates. Lines are parallel and evenly spaced.

the field inside a solenoid.error: Inside a long solenoid, the field is approximately uniform.
the field inside a solenoid.fix: The magnetic field inside a solenoid is parallel and nearly constant in strength.
the field inside a solenoid.action: Draw field inside solenoid. Lines are parallel along the axis.

gravity near Earth's surface.error: Near Earth's surface, gravity is approximately uniform for practical purposes.
gravity near Earth's surface.fix: Over small distances near Earth, g ≈ 9.8 N/kg is treated as uniform.
gravity near Earth's surface.action: Dropping objects in a lab? Treat g as uniform. Launching satellites? Non-uniform.

persistent.gap: You're not recognising the standard examples of each field type.
persistent.action: Non-uniform: radial fields from point sources, planetary fields at large scale, dipoles.

field_line_representation.name: Field Line Representation
field_line_representation.formula: Spacing shows strength, direction shows force
field_line_representation.correct: In field diagrams, closer lines indicate stronger fields. Parallel evenly-spaced lines indicate uniform fields.

closer lines mean weaker field.error: Opposite. Closer lines mean stronger field.
closer lines mean weaker field.fix: Field strength ∝ line density. More lines per area = stronger field.
closer lines mean weaker field.action: Near a point charge, lines are close together = strong field.

line direction shows field motion.error: Field lines don't move. They show force direction on a test particle.
line direction shows field motion.fix: Field line direction shows the direction a positive test charge would be pushed.
line direction shows field motion.action: Field lines are a snapshot showing force direction, not particle motion.

lines can cross in non-uniform fields.error: Field lines never cross, regardless of field type.
lines can cross in non-uniform fields.fix: If lines crossed, there would be two force directions at one point. Impossible.
lines can cross in non-uniform fields.action: At any point, there's one field direction. Lines never cross.

persistent.action: Closer lines = stronger. Parallel evenly spaced = uniform. Lines never cross.

static_vs_uniform_distinction.name: Static vs Uniform Distinction
static_vs_uniform_distinction.correct: Static and uniform are independent properties. Static describes constancy in time; uniform describes constancy across space.

static fields are always uniform.fix: A field can be static but non-uniform (Earth's gravity) or changing but uniform (EM wave in free space).
static fields are always uniform.action: Earth's gravity: static (doesn't change with time) but non-uniform (varies with altitude).

uniform fields are always static.error: Uniformity and constancy in time are separate.
uniform fields are always static.fix: A uniform field can change in time. Example: uniform E-field between plates with changing voltage.
uniform fields are always static.action: AC voltage on parallel plates: uniform in space, changing in time.

they mean the same thing.fix: Static = time invariance. Uniform = spatial invariance. Completely different axes.
they mean the same thing.action: Draw a 2×2 table: static/changing vs uniform/non-uniform. Fill in examples for all four.

persistent.gap: You're conflating time and space properties of fields.
persistent.action: Always ask separately: Does it change with time? (static/changing) Does it vary with position? (uniform/non-uniform)

gravitational_field_classification.name: Gravitational Field Classification
gravitational_field_classification.formula: Usually static, uniform only near surface
gravitational_field_classification.correct: Gravitational fields from stationary masses are static. They are non-uniform overall but approximately uniform near planetary surfaces.

always uniform.error: Gravitational fields from point masses are non-uniform.
always uniform.fix: g decreases with altitude following 1/r². Only near-surface approximation is uniform.
always uniform.action: Calculate g at surface vs 1000 km altitude. It's different. Non-uniform.

always changing.error: If the mass is stationary, the field is static.
always changing.fix: Earth's gravitational field is static because Earth's mass distribution doesn't change rapidly.
always changing.action: Does g at your location change from second to second? No. Static field.

changing because Earth rotates.error: Rotation affects apparent weight, not the gravitational field itself.
changing because Earth rotates.fix: The gravitational field depends on mass distribution, which doesn't change with rotation.
changing because Earth rotates.action: Rotation adds centrifugal effects but doesn't change the actual gravitational field.

persistent.gap: You're not classifying gravitational fields correctly.
persistent.action: Stationary mass = static field. Near surface = approximately uniform. Large scale = non-uniform.

magnetic_field_classification.name: Magnetic Field Classification
magnetic_field_classification.correct: Magnetic fields are static if the magnet is stationary or the current is constant. They are changing if the source moves or current varies.

always changing because of electron moti.error: Bulk field is static even if electrons move microscopically.
always changing because of electron moti.fix: In a stationary magnet, microscopic currents are steady on average, producing a static field.
always changing because of electron moti.action: Bar magnet sitting on table: field at any point is constant. Static.

always non-uniform.error: Some configurations produce uniform magnetic fields.
always non-uniform.fix: Inside a long solenoid, the magnetic field is approximately uniform.
always non-uniform.action: MRI machines use solenoids to create uniform magnetic fields.

static only if no current flows.error: Constant (DC) current produces static magnetic field.
static only if no current flows.fix: A wire with steady DC current creates a static magnetic field around it.
static only if no current flows.action: Constant current → constant magnetic field → static.

persistent.gap: You're misclassifying magnetic fields based on the wrong criteria.
persistent.action: Check: Is the current constant or varying? Is the magnet moving or stationary? Answer determines static/changing.

static_changing.title: Understanding Static and Changing Fields
static_changing.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of static and changing fields.

sentences.text: A static field is one that does not change over {{d1}}. The field strength at any given point remains {{d2}} as time passes.

d1.tooltip: What variable determines if a field is static?

d2.tooltip: What happens to field strength in a static field?

sentences.text: Static electric fields are created by {{d3}} charged particles. Static magnetic fields are created by {{d4}} magnets or wires carrying {{d5}} current.

d3.tooltip: What type of charge creates a static E-field?

d4.tooltip: What type of magnet creates a static B-field?

d5.tooltip: What type of current creates a static B-field?

sentences.text: A changing field varies in {{d6}} or direction over time. Moving charges create {{d7}} fields, not static ones.

d6.tooltip: What property of the field varies in a changing field?

d7.tooltip: Moving charges create what type of field?

uniform_nonuniform.title: Understanding Uniform and Non-uniform Fields
uniform_nonuniform.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of uniform and non-uniform fields.

sentences.text: A uniform field has the same {{d1}} and {{d2}} at all points in space. In a field diagram, this is shown by {{d3}} that are evenly spaced.

d1.tooltip: What stays constant in a uniform field?

d2.tooltip: What else stays constant besides magnitude?

d3.tooltip: How do uniform field lines appear?

sentences.text: A non-uniform field varies in strength or direction across {{d4}}. The field around a point mass or point charge is {{d5}} because it follows the inverse square law.

d5.tooltip: What type of field do point sources create?

sentences.text: The electric field between parallel charged plates is {{d6}}. Near Earth's surface, the gravitational field is approximately {{d7}} for practical calculations.

d6.tooltip: What type of field exists between parallel plates?

static_changing.title: Applying Static and Changing Field Concepts
static_changing.instructions: Apply your understanding of static and changing fields to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A bar magnet resting on a table produces a {{d1}} magnetic field because the magnet is {{d2}}. If you move the magnet back and forth, the field becomes {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: What type of field does a stationary magnet produce?

d3.tooltip: What happens when you move the source?

sentences.text: An electromagnet connected to a DC power supply produces a {{d4}} magnetic field. If connected to an AC power supply, the field becomes {{d5}} because the current {{d6}} over time.

d4.tooltip: What type of field does constant current produce?

d5.tooltip: What type of field does AC produce?

d6.tooltip: What does AC current do over time?

sentences.text: Earth's gravitational field is considered {{d7}} because Earth's mass distribution does not change rapidly. The field at any location remains {{d8}} from moment to moment.

d7.tooltip: Does Earth's gravitational field change with time?

uniform_nonuniform.title: Applying Uniform and Non-uniform Field Concepts
uniform_nonuniform.instructions: Apply your understanding of uniform and non-uniform fields to these scenarios.

sentences.text: In field diagrams, field lines that are closer together indicate a {{d1}} field. Lines that diverge outward from a point source show a {{d2}} field.

d2.tooltip: What type of field has diverging lines?

sentences.text: At sea level, g ≈ 9.8 N/kg. At the top of a tall mountain, g is {{d3}}. This shows that Earth's gravitational field is actually {{d4}} over large distances.

d3.tooltip: How does g change with altitude?

d4.tooltip: If g varies with position, what type of field is it?

sentences.text: The field inside a long solenoid carrying current is approximately {{d5}} because the field lines are {{d6}} and evenly spaced throughout the interior.

d5.tooltip: What type of field exists inside a solenoid?

d6.tooltip: How do lines appear in a uniform field?

static_changing.title: Mastering Static and Changing Field Classification
static_changing.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by distinguishing subtle cases and avoiding common errors.

sentences.text: A common error is thinking static and uniform mean the same thing. Static refers to constancy in {{d1}}, while uniform refers to constancy across {{d2}}. A field can be static but {{d3}}.

d3.tooltip: Can a static field vary with position?

sentences.text: Earth's gravitational field is {{d4}} because it doesn't change with time, but {{d5}} because field strength varies with altitude. These are {{d6}} properties.

d4.tooltip: Does Earth's gravity change over time?

d5.tooltip: Does Earth's gravity vary with position?

d6.tooltip: How are static and uniform related?

sentences.text: When classifying any field, ask two separate questions: Does it change with {{d7}}? (static or changing) Does it vary across {{d8}}? (uniform or non-uniform)

d7.tooltip: What variable determines static vs changing?

d8.tooltip: What variable determines uniform vs non-uniform?

uniform_nonuniform.title: Mastering Uniform and Non-uniform Field Classification
uniform_nonuniform.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by applying correct classification to various scenarios.

sentences.text: The gravitational field of a planet follows the inverse square law: g ∝ 1/r². This mathematical relationship proves the field is {{d1}}. However, close to the surface where distance changes are small, we approximate it as {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What does 1/r² tell us about spatial variation?

d2.tooltip: How do we treat g for small-scale calculations?

sentences.text: Between two parallel charged plates, the electric field has {{d3}} magnitude at all points and field lines are {{d4}}. This is why particle accelerators use parallel plates to provide {{d5}} acceleration.

d3.tooltip: What is the magnitude like in a uniform field?

d4.tooltip: How do lines appear in a uniform field?

d5.tooltip: What type of acceleration does a uniform field provide?

sentences.text: A bar magnet creates a {{d6}} field because the field lines curve from north to south pole and are closer together near the poles where the field is {{d7}}.

d6.tooltip: What type of field has curved, variably spaced lines?

d7.tooltip: What does closer line spacing indicate?
